page.title: 8.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will encounter a problem that cannot be easily solved by familiar strategies. After exploring different ways to solve the problem, you will write a quadratic equation to model the situation. You will also interpret what the solution to that equation means in the given context.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain the meaning of a solution to an equation in terms of a situation.
  • Write a quadratic equation that represents a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.1.1: Understanding a Situation with Quadratic Equations
  • 8.1.2: Modeling a Quadratic Problem
    • 8.1.2: Self Check
    • 8.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.1.3: Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model
    • 8.1.3: Self Check
    • 8.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.1.4: Interpreting a Solution

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 8.1.5: Practice
  • 8.1.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.1.1: Understanding a Situation with Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

A mechanical device is used to launch a potato vertically into the air. The potato is launched from a platform 20 feet above the ground, with an initial vertical velocity of 92 feet per second.

The function \(h(t) = -16t^2 + 92t + 20\) models the height of the potato over the ground, in feet, \(t\) seconds after launch.

Here is the graph representing the function.

For each question, explain your reasoning.


  1. What is the height of the potato 1 second after launch?

Enter the height of the potato 1 second after launch.

Compare your answer:

The height of the potato 1 second after launch will be 96 feet.
Substituting 1 second into the function \(h(t)\) yields:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}h(1)&=&-16{(1)}^2+20\\&=&-16+92+20\\&=&96\end{array}\)


  1. Will the potato still be in the air 8 seconds after launch?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

No, from the graph, we can see the potato will land before 8 seconds after the launch.


  1. Will the potato reach 120 feet? If so, when will it happen?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Yes, from the graph, we can see the potato’s height will be 120 feet at two times: approximately 1.5 seconds and 4.3 seconds after launch.


  1. When will the potato hit the ground, or have a height of zero feet?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

We can see from the graph the potato will hit the ground, or have a height of zero feet, after approximately 6 seconds.

page.title: 8.1.2: Modeling a Quadratic Problem
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a picture that is 7 inches by 4 inches, a piece of colored paper that measures 4 inches by 2.5 inches representing framing material, a ruler, and a pair of scissors.

Cut the framing material to create a rectangular frame for the picture. The frame should have the same width all the way around and have no overlaps. All of the framing material should be used with no leftover pieces. The frame should not cover any part of the picture.

Let’s review the information we know.

  • The picture measures 7 inches by 4 inches.
  • There are 10 square inches of framing material.
  • The frame must be uniform in width.
  • All of the framing material must be used.
  • The frame should not cover any part of the picture.

Describe the process you used to create the frame.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is an example of the process shown in images.


Now that you have completed the activity, can you think of any mathematical method to solve the problem?


Extending Your Thinking

Juan says, “The perimeter of the picture is 22 inches. If I cut the framing material into 9 pieces, each one being 2.5 inches by \(\frac {4}{9}\) inch, I’ll have more than enough material to surround the picture because those pieces would yield \(9 \cdot 2.5\), or 22.5 inches for the frame.”

Do you agree with Juan? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, Juan is not correct because 9 pieces would not be enough to go around the frame. While the total length of those pieces is enough to surround the picture, he will need at least two pieces for each short side to cover 4 inches and at least 3 pieces for each long side to cover 7 inches. This adds up to 10 pieces, as shown below.

page.title: 8.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: Suppose you want to frame a picture that measures 8 inches by 3 inches. The frame is created from 12 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used. Which statement is true?

answer.answer_text: The frame will measure exactly 8 inches by 3 inches.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The frame cannot have the same dimensions as the picture. Its dimensions will be longer to include the width of the frame. The true statement is that the total area of the framed picture will be 36 square inches: 24 square inches for the picture and 12 square inches for the frame. \(24 + 12 = 36\) square inches.

answer.answer_text: The total area of the framed picture will be 24 square inches.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The area of the picture by itself is \(8 \cdot 3\), or 24 square inches. The area of the framing material is 12 square inches. To find the total area, these values must be added together. The answer is the total area of the framed picture will be \(24 + 12\), or 36 square inches.

answer.answer_text: The perimeter of the framed picture will be 22 inches.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The perimeter of the picture by itself is \(8 + 8 + 3 + 3\), or 22 inches. The framed picture will have a larger perimeter than 22 inches. The true statement is that the total area of the framed picture will be 36 square inches: 24 square inches for the picture and 12 square inches for the frame. \(24 + 12 = 36\) square inches.

answer.answer_text: The total area of the framed picture will be 36 square inches.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The area of the picture is \(8 \cdot 3\), or 24 square inches. The area of the frame material is 12 square inches. So, the total area of the framed picture will be \(24 + 12\), or 36 square inches.

page.title: 8.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Modeling a Quadratic Problem

This activity challenges you to complete a very difficult task!

Let’s review the information we know from the picture in the Self Check.

  • The picture measures 8 inches by 3 inches.
  • There are 12 square inches of framing material.
  • The frame must be uniform in width.
  • All of the framing material must be used.
  • The frame should not cover any part of the picture.

What other information can you learn from the situation?

  • The perimeter of the picture is \(8 + 8 + 3 + 3\), or 22 inches. The framed picture will have a perimeter greater than this.
  • If the picture is 8 inches by 3 inches, then the area of the picture is \(8 \cdot 3\), or 24 square inches.
  • Since there are 12 square inches of framing material and all of it must be used, the framed picture will have an area of \(24 + 12\), or 36 square inches.

The more you know about the situation, the closer you are to being able to solve this problem mathematically instead of guessing and checking to see if you are correct.

We will use this information in later activities to set up a quadratic equation that can be used to solve the problem.

Try It: Modeling a Quadratic Problem

Suppose you want to frame a different picture that measures 10 inches by 6 inches. The frame is created from 36 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used.

  1. What is the perimeter of the picture?
  1. What is the area of the picture?
  1. What will be the total area of the framed picture?

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the missing information about the framed picture:

  1. The perimeter of the picture is \(10 + 10 + 6 + 6 = 32\) inches.
  1. The area of the picture is \(10 \cdot 6 = 60\) square inches.
  1. The total area of the framed picture will be \(60 + 36 = 96\) square inches.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.1.3: Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model
page.contents:
Activity

Here is a diagram that shows the picture with a frame that is the same width all the way around.

The picture is 7 inches by 4 inches. The frame is created from 10 square inches of framing material (in the form of a rectangle measuring 4 inches by 2.5 inches).


  1. Write an expression to represent the length of the framed picture on its shorter side. Use \(x\) to represent the width of the frame.

Enter an expression to represent the length of the framed picture on its shorter side.

Compare your answer:

\(2x + 4\)


  1. Write an expression to represent the length of the framed picture on its longer side. Use \(x\) to represent the width of the frame.

Enter an expression to represent the length of the framed picture on its longer side.

Compare your answer:

\(2x + 7\)


  1. Use the expressions from the previous exercises to write an equation to represent the relationship between the measurements of the framed picture and its total area. Be prepared to explain what each part of your equation represents.

Enter an equation to represent the relationship between the measurements of the framed picture and its total area.

Compare your answer:

\((2x + 7)(2x + 4) = 38\) or \(4x^2 + 22x + 28 = 38\) (or equivalent)


  1. What would a solution to this equation mean in this situation?

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

A solution would represent the width of the frame when all of the framing material is used.


Video: Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model

Watch the following video to learn more about formulating a quadratic equation to represent the model.

page.title: 8.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: Suppose a different picture is 5 inches by 5 inches. The frame is created from 11 square inches of framing material. The frame will be uniform in width, and all of the framing material is used. Which equation would you need to solve to determine the value of \(x\), the width of the frame?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The length of one side of the frame is \(2x + 5\). The area of the framed picture is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5)\). Set this equal to the total area, \(25 + 11\), or 36 square inches. So, the equation to represent the total area is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5) = 36\), or \(4x^2 + 20x + 25 = 36\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The length of one side of the frame is \(2x + 5\). So the area of the framed picture is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5)\). Remember to add the products of the inner terms and outer terms when multiplying the binomials. Set this equal to the total area, \(25 + 11\), or 36 square inches. The answer, or the equation to represent the total area, is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5) = 36\), or \(4x^2 + 20x + 25 = 36\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This represents only part of the frame. The length of one side of the frame is \(2x + 5\). So the area of the framed picture is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5)\). Set this equal to the total area, \(25 + 11\), or 36 square inches. The answer, or the equation to represent the total area, is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5) = 36\), or \(4x^2 + 20x + 25 = 36\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The length of one side of the frame is \(2x + 5\). So the area of the framed picture is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5)\). Set this equal to the total area, \(25 + 11\), or 36 square inches. Remember to add the products of the last terms of each binomial when multiplying the two binomials. The answer, or the equation to represent the total area, is \((2x + 5)(2x + 5) = 36\), or \(4x^2 + 20x + 25 = 36\).

page.title: 8.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model

Let’s look at a similar situation to the previous activities but using a picture with different measurements.

Imagine a picture 8 inches by 6 inches. The frame is created from 32 square inches of framing material. The frame will be uniform in width, and all of the framing material is used.

How do we write an equation representing the total area of the framed picture?

Let’s break down the measurements that we know.

Let \(x\) represent the thickness of the frame in inches.

Since the picture is 8 inches by 6 inches, it has an area of 48 square inches.

The frame is created from 32 square inches of framing material, and we must use all of it. So, the total area of the framed picture is \(48 + 32\), or 80 square inches.

The length of one side of the framed picture is \(x + 6 + x = 2x + 6\).

The length of the other side of the framed picture is \(x + 8 + x = 2x + 8\).

So, the area of the framed picture is \((2x + 8)(2x + 6)\). We can set this equal to 80 square inches.

\((2x + 8)(2x + 6) = 80\)

Let’s multiply.

\(4x^2 + 12x + 16x + 48 = 80\)

\(4x^2 + 28x + 48 = 80\)

So, the equation representing the total area of the framed picture is \(4x^2 + 28x + 48 = 80\).

This equation is a quadratic equation. A quadratic equation is defined as one that can be written in the form \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), where \(a\) is not 0.

Try It: Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model

A picture measures 9 inches by 7 inches. Its frame is created from 36 square inches of framing material. The frame will be uniform in width, and all of the framing material is used.

Write an equation representing the total area of the framed picture.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the quadratic equation to represent the total area of the framed picture:

The area of the picture is 63 square inches. The total area of the framed picture will be \(63 + 36\), or 99 square inches.

The sides of the framed picture are represented by \((2x + 9)\) and \((2x + 7)\).

So, the total area of the framed picture is represented by \(4x^2 + 32x + 63 = 99\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.1.4: Interpreting a Solution
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A framed picture has a total area \(y\), in square inches. The thickness of the frame is represented by \(x\), in inches. The equation \(y = (2x + 8)(2x + 10)\) relates these two variables.


  1. What is the width, or shorter side, of the picture without the frame?

Enter the width.

Compare your answer:

8 inches


  1. What is the length, or longer side, of the picture without the frame?

Enter the length.

Compare your answer:

10 inches


  1. What would a solution to the equation \(100 = (2x + 8)(2x + 10)\) mean in this situation?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The solution would represent the thickness of a frame that results in a total area of 100 square inches.

page.title: 8.1.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–3.

A water balloon is launched by a catapult into the air. The water balloon is launched from 4 feet above the ground, with an initial vertical velocity of 40 feet per second.

The function \(h(t)=-16t^2 + 40t + 4\) models the height of the water balloon over the ground, in feet, \(t\) seconds after launch.

  1. What is the height of the water balloon 1 second after launch?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 28 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Will the water balloon still be in the air 2 seconds after the launch?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Using the graph, estimate when the water balloon hit the ground.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is approximately 2.6 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 4–5.

Suppose you want to frame a different picture that measures 12 inches by 9 inches. The frame is created from 46 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used.

  1. Which of the following is true about the situation described?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the perimeter of the framed picture is greater than 42 inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the total area of the framed picture?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 154 square inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 6–8.

Suppose you want to frame a different picture that measures 9 inches by 8 inches. The frame is created from 38 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used. Let \(x\) represent the thickness of the frame.

  1. What is the total area of the framed picture?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 110 square inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the measurements of the picture and of the frame and the area of the framed picture.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(4x^2 + 34x + 72 = 110\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does the solution to the equation in the previous question represent in this situation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the thickness of the frame when all of the framing material is used. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 9–10.

A framed picture has a total area \(y\), in square inches. The thickness of the frame is represented by \(x\), in inches. The equation \(y = (2x + 5)(2x + 7)\) relates these two variables.

  1. What are the width and length of the picture without the frame?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5 inches and 7 inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following represents the area of the frame?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y - 35\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.1.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the meaning of a solution to an equation in terms of a situation.
  • Write a quadratic equation that represents a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.1.1: Understanding a Situation with Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you analyzed a graph representing a situation represented by a quadratic equation. You then used the graph to describe the situation.
  • 8.1.2: Modeling a Quadratic Problem
    • In this activity, you attempted to solve a problem that was represented by a quadratic equation using any method possible, including guess and check.
    • 8.1.2: Self Check
    • 8.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.1.3: Formulating a Quadratic Equation to Represent the Model
    • In this activity, you learned how to write a quadratic equation to represent the given situation. You also learned how to interpret the solution to this equation.
    • 8.1.3: Self Check
    • 8.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.1.4: Interpreting a Solution
    • In this activity, you used a quadratic equation to draw conclusions about a given situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.1.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
